Advehnt Guard
Avengard / hav-kerloe
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 2:01 PM
Hav woke up in his bed.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 4:23 PM
((am I allowed to have a fish tank in my bedroom)) (edited)
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 4:24 PM
((Yes))
4:24 PM
((I'm pretty sure you listed it too))
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 5:03 PM
I wake up. Another morning. I look out my window and see the city of Avengard from my apartment. I have the same thought I have every morningâ€”thousands of people are also waking up now. Very interesting. It's Monday. As the owner of Kerloe Fishery, I work all seven days of the week, but business only truly is active on the weekdays. Exponentially more people will be present than they were yesterday and the day before, which is good. Mondays are interesting. They're clearly different from the two days before them, and according to society, those two days are better. There's not really a difference, we've just assigned things to work this way. I'm reminded of the famous comic strip cat Carlfield, who is known for hating Mondays. Why does the cat hate Mondays? The reason people hate Mondays is because they have to work, and they didn't have to work on the two previous days. However, cats don't need to work, do they? Cats are animals. That's the thing about Carlfield, and all the cats like him. They don't need to do anything. Carlfield hates Mondays because humans hate Mondays. Humans hate Mondays because there is a collective agreement that Mondays should work this way. So, what's the point in Carlfield putting in energy to rebel against the idea of hating Mondays? It's much simpler for him to accept that Mondays are bad, and to hate them. Carlfield is not funny. I'm not sure why John David's comic strip cat is so popular when there are so many other comic strips just like it out there. I'd guess it was because he was one of the first to do it. I myself understand John David's methods, as I was one of the first to open a fish store in the city of Avengard. There are other fish stores now, because people see success and wish to emulate it, but since I was the first, I am the most successful. I look towards the tank of fish in my room. I open a tube of fish food, and give it to the fish. I'm keeping the fish alive. Why? For the same reason that I go to work and sell fish, or for the same reason Carlfield eats his lasagna. Very simply, I'm not sure. We just do it. I'd love to speak to John David about his decision to make Carlfield eat lasagna. Lasagna is fascinating, because it combines pasta, sauce, and meat. Meat is the result of us looking at an animal that cannot communicate anything to us, and saying that its life must be used to make food. Food tastes good. Something tasting good is good, because we like it. Carlfield, however, is equally as much a commodity as the cows that result in his lasagna. He's bought by James Carlbuckle and kept as a pet. Just like the fish I just fed. However, fish are arguably the ideal animal, because they can be treated with pure equality. At the fish store, I sell fish as food to be eaten. At home, I keep fish as pets. I can visit the ocean, and see fish in the wild, living their lives to the fullest, with no human intervention. Fish are truly incredible. With the thoughts of Carlfield in my mind, I exit the bedroom. I chuckle thinking about the infamous "pipe strip", in which Carlfield steals James's pipe. I am not amused because Carlfield is funny, but because of how absurd this joke is. It's barely even a joke. It's amusing how bad of a joke it is. (edited)
5:03 PM
((if nothing happens to me after I exit my bedroom, I will continue))
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 5:07 PM
Hav is not interrupted.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 5:38 PM
There are three rooms in my apartment, and I enter the second one. It is a kitchen, but I prefer to call it the fish room, because there are several fish tanks in it. Ironically, the fish room is also where I cook and eat fish. As much as I would love to cook a delicious fish breakfast, my work takes priority. I enter the third and final room of the apartment, the restroom. I brush my teethâ€”an important activity, though I'm unsure why. I wonder if Carlfield brushes his teeth. He takes the idea of hating Mondays from humans, despite it being meaningless to him, so why not brushing teeth as well? Finally, I feed the many fish in the fish room. I wonder which is more importantâ€”feeding the fish, or brushing my teeth? What a fascinating dilemma. However, the answer is obviousâ€”of course feeding the fish is more important. Brushing my teeth does not keep me alive. Feeding the fish does keep them alive. If I stopped feeding the fish, it would affect their lives, it would kill them. As the owner of a fish store, I am responsible for the deaths of many fish. Of course, the lives of fish are unimportant. I don't know why this is, but it's true. I'm suddenly struck with an idea. I reach my hand into one of the tanks, and take a fish out of it. I rush to my bedroom with the squirming fish in my hand, and open the window. I then drop the still living fish out of it, onto the streets of Avengard below. I close the window, and return to the fish room. I'm spreading fish to the people. What a wonderful thought, someone being able to witness the death of a fish right before their eyes. Will they understand? Will they see that this doesn't matter, because society has told them that this fish's life is meaningless? Will they be confused as to why a fish is dying right in front of them? They shouldn't be. Why would a fish's death only matter if you specifically are the one who witnesses it? Like Carlfield eating his lasagna, people are ignorant to the idea that things must happen to cause their everyday activities. Yes. I will write to John David and tell him my idea. I grab a pen and a piece of paper, and begin to write. To John David, creator of Carlfield I think that it would be very interesting if you were to have a Carlfield comic strip in which Carlfield must confront the ways his beloved lasagna is made. He would be disgusted at first, but he would realize that there is no reason to be discomforted by this, and understand that he always knew that his lasagna would be made like this. Seeing it makes no difference. This realization could also potentially spur Carlfield into understanding why his hatred of Mondays is illogicalâ€”he is a cat, not a human. Human logic does not matter to him. I do not require credit for use of my idea. Thank you, Hav Kerloe (owner of Kerloe Fishery) I place the letter in an envelope, then attach the requisite postage stamps to the envelope. I wonder how I will find out where to send this letter for it to reach John David. I don't use the internet, so looking it up there would not be possible. I decide that I will ask the next person I communicate with to search it for me. I take the letter and a pen and place them in my pocket. I then take my keys and exit my apartment. (edited)
5:38 PM
((if nothing happens to me after I exit my apartment, I will continue))
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 5:45 PM
Hav is not interrupted after exiting his apartment.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 6:18 PM
I exit my apartment and lock the door behind meâ€”I wouldn't want someone to break in and steal my fish. I walk towards the stairs, but as I am about to open the door, I realize something. I need to encounter someone, so I can ask them where to send my letter. Thus, I decide to take the elevator to the ground floor, something I never do. The elevator has a higher chance of having someone in it, which wouldn't be good. However, in this case, it would be good. Therefore, I press the button to call the elevator, and wait for it to arrive.
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 6:22 PM
The elevator opened, revealing no one inside.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 6:23 PM
((Is there anything of note in the elevator besides normal elevator things?))
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 6:28 PM
((There is not))
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 6:30 PM
I press every single button below the floor I am in (25), and wait. Since I usually don't take elevators, I want to take as much advantage of the elevator situation as possible. If I don't get the full elevator experience, is there really a point?
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 6:39 PM
No one enters the elevator.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 6:41 PM
When I reach the ground floor, I exit the elevator.
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 6:47 PM
There's an old man in the lobby.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 6:48 PM
I walk up to the old man in the lobby. Do I recognize the old man in the lobby?
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 6:50 PM
The old man is unfamiliar.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 6:54 PM
A person. Perfect. A human is exactly what I am looking for. I think about how to phrase my question. I need to know if this old man uses the internet or not. There are several ways to do this, but with someone so old, it's probably best to ask in a straightforward manner. "Do you use the internet?"
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 6:56 PM
"Does anyone not?"
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 7:03 PM
This is going very well. "Does anyone not?" clearly implies that this old man thinks that everyone uses the internet. Which, of course, tells me that he himself uses the internet, because why would someone who doesn't use the internet not know that people who don't use the internet exist? It's simple logic, but it leads me to a very useful conclusion. I can ask this man for help. "Could you please do me a favor and look up where to send fan letters to John David, creator of Carlfield?"
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 7:03 PM
"Huh? Uh, sure man." He pulls out his phone and goes through it.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 7:04 PM
I wait.
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 7:07 PM
"His email is jdavid@carlfield.com." (edited)
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 7:10 PM
No, no. This is all wrong. This man's misconception, one that worked towards my benefit before, is now coming back to hurt me. He thinks that, since everyone uses the internet, that an email would be helpful to me. Of course, it isn't. I need to salvage this situation, and fast. "Not email. I don't use email. I mean an address, somewhere I can send a physical letter to."
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 7:14 PM
"You don't use email? Okay, fine. The address is 5440 East Co. Road 450N, Albany, Indiana 47320, United States." He read off his phone.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 7:16 PM
"Thank you." Are there any tables in the lobby?
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 7:21 PM
There's a seating area near the reception desk with tables.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 7:21 PM
I walk to the seating area and sit down at the seating area. Are there any people around besides the old man from the internet?
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 7:27 PM
The receptionist is there as well.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 7:33 PM
I do not pay any attention to the receptionist. I take out the pen and envelope, and write "5440 East Co. Road 450N, Albany, Indiana 47320, United States" in the center of the envelope, and the return address (my address) in the top left. I am now ready to send it. I walk outside of the apartment complex, and thinking of that phrase makes me remember the irony of using a word such as "complex" to describe something so simple. (edited)
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 7:34 PM

Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 7:36 PM
I know where the nearest post office is, so I walk towards it. It is a small detour from my normal walk to the fish store, where I work.
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 7:38 PM
The post office is exactly as it would usually be.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 7:39 PM
I put the letter into a mailbox, officially sending my words to John David. I do not pay attention to anyone on the street or at the post office. If nothing else of note happens, I walk to the fish store, where I work.

Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 8:19 PM
Great. I walk past them, not saying a word, and unlock the door. I stand behind the counter where people go when they want to buy things, and wait. (edited)

Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 8:30 PM

Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 8:51 PM
I stand there thinking about those two identical interactions. I wonder what these people thought when they bought their fish. I see both of them very often, so a logical deduction is that they enjoy the taste of fish. Are they really any different from fish, though? They come here, like any other customer, and their destiny is to buy their fish, then leave. How simple and predictable. I could have guessed exactly what they would do the moment I saw them. I'm the same way, aren't I? I'd sell them their fish, because I need to. Because selling fish is good. I stand there thinking about those two identical interactions. I wonder what these people thought when they bought their fish. I see both of them very often, so a logical deduction is that they enjoy the taste of fish. Are they really any different from fish, though? They come here, like any other customer, and their destiny is to buy their fish, then leave. How simple and predictable. I could have guessed exactly what they would do the moment I saw them. I'm the same way, aren't I? I'd sell them their fish, because I need to. Because selling fish is good. I stand there thinking about those two identical interactions. I wonder what these people thought when they bought their fish. I see both of them very often, so a logical deduction is that they enjoy the taste of fish. Are they really any different from fish, though? They come here, like any other customer, and their destiny is to buy their fish, then leave. How simple and predictable. I could have guessed exactly what they would do the moment I saw them. I'm the same way, aren't I? I'd sell them their fish, because I need to. Because selling fish is good. I stand there thinking about those two identical interactions. I wonder what these people thought when they bought their fish. I see both of them very often, so a logical deduction is that they enjoy the taste of fish. Are they really any different from fish, though? They come here, like any other customer, and their destiny is to buy their fish, then leave. How simple and predictable. I could have guessed exactly what they would do the moment I saw them. I'm the same way, aren't I? I'd sell them their fish, because I need to. Because selling fish is good. I stand there thinking about those two identical interactions. I wonder what these people thought when they bought their fish. I see both of them very often, so a logical deduction is that they enjoy the taste of fish. Are they really any different from fish, though? They come here, like any other customer, and their destiny is to buy their fish, then leave. How simple and predictable. I could have guessed exactly what they would do the moment I saw them. I'm the same way, aren't I? I'd sell them their fish, because I need to. Because selling fish is good. I repeat this thought many more times, until something else happens.

Sam entered.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 9:14 PM
Fascinating. They both did the same exact thing again. Let me guess, tomorrow they'll come back and do the same thing yet again. This is just like Carlfield, isn't it? Every day, there's a new comic. Every week, there's a new Monday, a new opportunity for Cats and humans might be closer than I thought. They all keep on doing the same thing. Carlfield keeps on eating his lasagna. These customers keep on buying and eating their fish. I keep selling fish, because I need to. Because selling fish is good. I do not react to Sam entering until he says something. ((#hav-and-sam))

Avengard / hav-and-sam
Sam Kidink 5/28/2022 9:10 PM
"Hi, Mr. Kerloe. How are you today?" Sam enters Kerloe Fishery. (edited)
9:10 PM
[what's the name of the fish store anyway?]
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 9:11 PM
((Kerloe Fishery))
1
9:14 PM
"I'm good, Sam."
Sam Kidink 5/28/2022 9:20 PM
For example, Hav Kerloe. I've been to the fish store at least a few times, and he's definitely one of the more interesting people I've talked to, at least, Sam thinks to himself. "Glad to hear. I'll place my usual order, if that's alright." Sam places his usual order and finds somewhere to sit. "Anything interesting happen today?"
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 9:27 PM
"Anything interesting"? My revelations about Carlfield are certainly interesting. The fact that people have come in and bought fish again and again is interesting. The city of Avengard is interesting, considering how many people are in it. The fish I am selling are interesting. All kinds of different fish, all kinds of different tastes. All of them were once alive. I wonder how they would taste if I ate them while they were alive? I'm surprised I haven't tried that yet, it seems obvious. Why do people need to wait until fish is dead to eat it? Plenty of this fish is raw, after all, so is it really that different? I stare into space for a few seconds thinking this, before registering the fact that Sam made an order. I go to his table and provide him with his meal. "The usual events are interesting. It's interesting to see the same customers come in again." "Here is your fish. That will be $X.XX. Thank you for shopping at Kerloe Fishery." (edited)
Sam Kidink 5/28/2022 9:31 PM
[the spoiler tagged inner monologue is a good idea I should do that in conversations like this]
Sam Kidink 5/28/2022 9:38 PM
[inner monologue, wait until after the session end] This is one of the things I'm talking about. He somehow seems to find enjoyment in all the day-to-day events, which is definitely a contrast to me. Well, that's on the surface, anyway. It could be because of his job, I suppose. It's hard to say for sure what he's thinking at any given time, but as I said, he's a relatively interesting person because of that. I don't meet many people with opinions on 'usual events' at all. That reminds me, I could try to ask about the café. But I don't think Mr. Kerloe would have any information regarding that. "Are you sure about that? I can't say I find a lot of daily events interesting, and sometimes I wonder if you do either. Well, I guess it's not a huge deal." I pay for the fish and sit down again to eat. (edited)
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 9:54 PM
It's very ironic that Sam claims he doesn't find a lot of daily events interesting, because that might be the most unique thing I've seen today. Daily events are only the way that they are because they happen "daily", no? The idea that things happen the same way every day "just because" is so interesting. Sam here is questioning that, and his questioning is the closest thing I've seen today of someone who is willing to rebel against those same "daily events". That same question is also why he won't accomplish anything by thinking this. If you don't pay attention to the existence of the world's repetition and sameness, then despite being someone who can break the pattern, you won't be conscious enough to be able to make a meaningful difference. When you consider how Sam claimed "it's not a huge deal", it's clear he won't succeed. Sam also claimed that he wondered if I did either, implying that he thinks I am being dishonest with him. Of course, I would never lie to someone. Why? Because I don't want to. Carlfield saying that he hates Mondays is lying. He doesn't hate Mondays, he just hates the idea of them. Any person claiming that they hate Mondays would be a liar, because the thing they hate is the way society structures the days of the week, not the day itself. The reason the world exists in the state that it does is because everyone is a liar. The idea that I would be dishonest is laughable. Lying is thinking there is a chance to exit the state you are inâ€”there isn't. We are here because we want to be, and we should be satisfied with that. So, how should I respond? Should I even respond at all? It's possible that I could help Sam by giving a certain kind of response, but do I really need to? Does helping him really accomplish anything? I guess it would keep him coming back here, which would be good. The more time one spends around fish, the better a person they become, after all. If I help Sam, everyone wins. And he clearly needs help to "understand". Thus, I decide to respond in the kindest way possible, in hopes that it will encourage his continued patronage. "I hope you have a great day." (edited)
Sam Kidink 5/28/2022 10:22 PM
I eat the fish and think to myself. [inner monologue, wait until after the session end] Well, I guess he's not very interested in talking today. Maybe he wants me to leave earlier. That's a bit unusual, actually, even for Hav Kerloe. Maybe something's up? Well, it's probably best not to inquire on this, in line with what I said earlier. Maybe it's because I didn't have anything to say either that nothing happened this time. Well, as I said, this is one of the things that makes him interesting. Either he says things which happens to be interesting, or he says so little that that itself is fun to think about. I mean, he didn't even respond directly to what I said earlier, which I guess isn't that atypical, but who knows? ...Speaking of which, it's basically almost nighttime at this point, which means he got the time of day wrong. Did he get it wrong on his own, or did I get it wrong first? Or has he just not looked outside the fish store at all? Well, learning this probably isn't an interesting use of my time. Well, anyway, going to restaurants like this is nice. I'd rather eat out at places like this than at home, anyway, since I get some more time alone to think to myself like this. Even if there are other people who come here sometimes. I guess I could do this more in the future, considering I have a bit more freedom now than before. "Alright, have a good night, Mr. Kerloe." I finish eating, then leave the fish store. [sam: go to https://discord.com/channels/959192904184778753/979770545082093568/980298469166157864] (edited)
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 10:23 PM
"You too."

Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 10:59 PM

Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 11:00 PM
The stairs are empty.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 11:00 PM
I walk up the stairs to the 25th floor and open the door to exit the stairs.
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 11:00 PM
The corridor is empty.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 11:01 PM
I unlock my door and enter my apartment.
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 11:01 PM
The apartment is normal.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 11:10 PM
I turn on the oven and preheat it at 425 degrees Fahrenheit. I then wash my hands in the kitchen sink for exactly 40 seconds. I open the refrigerator, and take out a fresh salmon. I place the salmon on a cutting board, take a knife from the knife drawer, and cut it in several pieces. I remove the bones and discard the tail, but I keep the head, as it's the best part. I pour some olive oil on the pieces, then add salt and pepper. When the oven is finished preheating, I place the salmon in and set the timer for ten minutes. While waiting, I take a lemon from my lemon bowl (a bowl with lemons in it, no other fruits) and cut the lemon in half with the same knife and cutting board I used to cut the salmon. After the ten minutes are up, I take the salmon out of the oven and place it on a plate. I then squeeze the lemon halves onto it, and discard the remains of the lemon corpses. I then eat the salmon using a fork and a knife.
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 11:16 PM
It sure is a normal supper.
Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 11:16 PM
I then take a bottle of bottled water and drink the entire thing.
11:17 PM
After that, I brush my teeth, then enter my bed with the intention of sleeping.
Ehn/PC 5/28/2022 11:17 PM
Hav goes to sleep.

Ehn/PC 7/9/2022 1:40 PM
2: Advent Guards
Advehnt Guard
Avengard / hav-kerloe
Ehn/PC 6/18/2022 2:02 PM
Hav woke up in his bed.
Hav Kerloe 6/18/2022 3:36 PM
I wake up. Another morning. I look out my window and see the city from my apartment. I have the same thought I have every morningâ€”thousands of people are also waking up now. The city is called Avengard, and I'm not entirely sure why. I think about Shelk, the other city to the south of Avengard. Why are these two cities separate? This is the type of thing that the citizens of Avengard and Shelk are forced to ponder every day, I'm sure. It's Tuesday. Another day that I, as the owner of Kerloe Fishery, must work. This is good, because I get to make money, which helps me survive. Tuesdays aren't quite as interesting as Mondays, as they are unrelated to Carlfield the cat, who is known for hating Mondays specifically. Tuesdays are a normal day, like all the others. What do Tuesdays do to stand out? Nothing. Tuesdays are, honestly, a failure of a day. I look towards the fish tank that I keep in my room. I then look towards the fish food tube placed next to it. I place my hand onto the tube's lid, and unscrew it. This process opens the tube, allowing the fish food within to exit the tube freely. It's interesting to note how, in the ocean, fish food doesn't exist. Fish simply must eat whatever is available to them. It's incredible how they are able to know what it is to eat, and they are blessed with the ability to access that at any time. When humans eat fish, we have to prepare them, make sure they are made in the right way. It's a process that is dedicated to taking the fish's existence and distilling it down to a "meal". The irony in that is that the fish themselves must be fed first with food of their own. Humans can't eat fish food. Why not? What's the problem with it? If the food goes into the fish, and the fish goes into us, then... This doesn't make sense at all. I stare at the open tube of fish food. I then pick it up and pour the contents of it into my mouth, and swallow.
3:39 PM
((if nothing happens to me after I eat the fish food, I will continue))
Ehn/PC 6/18/2022 3:41 PM
Unsurprisingly, this tastes awful.
Hav Kerloe 6/18/2022 4:50 PM
Surprisingly, the fish food tastes awful. Is this what the fish go through? Is this what humans force them to eat? This torture is what they must go through, sitting in tanks, consuming the most vile food imaginable, until their death? A death that dooms them to be food themselves. What a beautiful existence. Fish know what they are. They know they must eat to survive. They know that continuing to survive is a thing they must do. At the same time, they live in complete ignorance. They have nothing to compare themselves to, no way of knowing how much better it could be. I realize that, since I have swallowed all of the fish food, I don't have any fish food left to feed the fish with. This is bad. I must feed the fish. If I do not feed the fish, they will die. I cannot simply let the fish die. I'm not hungry, and it would be a waste. I've already introduced a live fish to the people yesterday, so they must understand. Doing it again would be pointless. I'm not sure what to do. ... It hits me. I will buy more fish food. I've figured out the solution to this dilemma. I exit the bedroom, satisfied that such an elegant solution to all of my problems has shown itself to me.
4:50 PM
((if nothing happens to me after I exit my bedroom, I will continue))
Ehn/PC 6/18/2022 4:53 PM
Nothing happens to Hav after he exits his room.
Hav Kerloe 6/18/2022 5:20 PM
I enter the second of the three rooms in my apartment, that I affectionately call the "fish room". The reason for this is because, contained within the room, are several fish tanks, each with several fish inside them. More fish that will suffer for my carelessness in swallowing all the fish food if I do not take action quickly. I always feed all of the fish every morning. Not doing so is very dangerous. I shouldn't do things like this, or soon enough everything will fall apart. The fish room, the room in which I feed the fish, is traditionally known as the "kitchen". The fact that it's used to cook does not make the "fish room" label any less accurate, as the only foods I cook and eat in this room are various types of fish. I then enter the restroom, which contains the toothbrush. I brush the remaining fish food flakes out of my teeth, taking note that this activity is important even if I don't begin the day by eating fish food. After turning on the water, rinsing the toothbrush, and turning the water off, I exit the bathroom. Then, I take the keys, and exit the apartment.

Talking to someone without a reason can only go badly. If there's no reason to do something, then you shouldn't do it. It's quite simple, but humans insist on creating connections where there are none, at great risk to themselves. Perhaps the old man is some sort of police officer, and the phone woman is a criminal. This seems like a reasonable possibility. She could also be a missing person, but if that was the case I doubt he'd have included the stipulation that she shouldn't be spoken to. Hav Kerloe 6/18/2022 7:24 PM
[inner monologue, don't read until after a good while] I take note of the person in a white suit whose face is completely obscured (with the exception of eyes) by bandages who is standing outside the hotel. What a strange appearance for a person to have. I suppose it makes sense, as appearance is generally irrelevant, and making your appearance indecipherable changes very little beyond preventing society's standards from being applied to you. However, it could be said to backfire as well. One who makes themselves appear in such an indecipherable manner will naturally attract even more attention than the average person, being examined and criticized for their desire to be different by disregarding a meaningless sense of individuality. There's a simple way to explain this. Let's imagine you have two different species of fishâ€”one brown, and one gray. A trout and a salmon. Both can be eaten, and both taste like fish. The tastes are distinct to anyone experienced with fish, however, would anything really change if they looked identical? I doubt it. People would barely notice that the two are actually different types of fish. Humans are the same. Take away our flesh, muscles, organs, and everything else, and we are left as simple skeletons. This is what happens to a corpse. Everything disappears, degrading into nothingness. Underneath it all, we're impossible to tell apart. You cannot determine a person's identity by their skeleton. A person's "true form" is one that removes all of their individuality. This person in front of me is embracing that. Very respectable. However, I have no time to dawdle over them. There are infinite tanks, with infinite fish. I will stay in my own. There are no other fish in my tank, and I absolutely cannot let this change, no matter what desires may come. Hav Kerloe 6/25/2022 4:23 PM
I take the keys out of the keyhole, then close the door behind me and lock it, all while balancing the cans with my left hand. I lock the door, despite not planning on spending much time at all in the apartment, because the idea of someone breaking in and attempting to steal the fish is unsettling. I then set the cans on the counter of the room that I call the "fish room", because of all the fish in it. Typically, this would be called the "kitchen", but I think "fish room" is a more accurate moniker. "Kitchen" is such a strange word. I wonder what its origin is. It tells you absolutely nothing about the type of room it describes. The world would be greatly improved if everyone put fish in their kitchen, then changed the name of the room from "kitchen" to "fish room". It would be a far more informative descriptor. The presence of fish would also allow humans to become far more attuned to the reality of existence, creating a world that has far less conflict. There are already fish populating kitchens all throughout the worldâ€”simply to be consumed, rather than to live. Instead of being life themselves, they sustain the life of other organisms. I don't see much of a difference here. I take one of the cans and unscrew the cap. I remove the protective film and place it in the trash. I then pour the requisite amount of food into each of the three fish tanks. I then have a brilliant flash of inspiration. I walk into the bedroom, open the window, and pour a bit of the fish food out of it. Perfect. First fish, now fish food. Through these simple actions, the world will improve. Perhaps, by some miracle, the fish food will land in the mouth of a person below. How incredible would that be? I want to believe it's true. We all eat fish food all the time, just in different forms. This will allow someone to come closer to waking up to this reality. One step at a time. I close the window, screw the cap back on the can, walk back to the fish room and place the can in a cabinet. I then take the rest of the cans and place them in the same cabinet. Afterwards, I unlock the door, walk out of the apartment, and use the keys to lock the door behind me. (edited)

Sam Kidink 6/25/2022 7:57 PM
[hi]
8:00 PM
Well, I would prefer to talk under more relaxing circumstances... I should probably get whatever happened on my phone out of the way first, though. "Hi, Mr. Kerloe. Something happened. Would you like to hear about it? However, I do have to check my phone first, if that's fine." (edited)
Hav Kerloe 6/25/2022 8:09 PM
[inner monologue, don't read until after the session is over] Something happened, huh? Things do seem to be happening at a more significant rate than usual lately. I wonder why that is? Sam asked me if I'd like to hear about what happened, which means I have an opportunity to deny that. He also needs to check his phone first, which is bizarre. If he needed to check his phone first, why didn't he do it before talking to me? His statement is illogical no matter how I look at it. He must have some other motive for telling me he needs to check his phone first. But, why would he ask me permission? Is it possible that asking me permission is simply misdirection for the true purpose of his statement, that being implanting the knowledge of him checking his phone into my mind? That seems the most likely scenario, but far from the only possibility. The fact that there's so much about this statement that doesn't make sense is in itself a clue to his true intentions. You don't accidentally create such a complex and layered statement. What if it's the other way around? What if he's not trying to subtly suggest something, but rather he's trying to directly tell me something? He could have someone watching him, so he can't say it directly. What if this is some kind of code? It's another possibility to consider, but I can't definitively come to any conclusions at the moment. The best course of action for now is to see what else he has to say. I'm sure he was planning on me saying I would like to hear about it, and I see no reason to do anything to go against his plans at present. "Sure."
Sam Kidink 6/25/2022 8:19 PM
Well, at least I can discuss the issue at hand... that's good. I'm sure I can get a good response out of this. Sam checks his phone and reads the text he received earlier on his own. [https://discord.com/channels/959192904184778753/979770545082093568/990412126466244639] "Thanks. Danger is a fallacy, an idea that comes from belief that one has individuality. In Sam's case, he subconsciously desires to return here when he feels danger. Every time he eats fish, every time he sees them being cut up and served, he understands more and more. The truth of the world is held within this place. I trust that Sam wouldn't do anything,. but this strange creature pretending to be a robot is a different story. I'll have to ask Sam to leave, and maybe he can take his friend with him. "Sam, could you perhaps take this conversation elsewhere? I can't leave a stranger in the store unattended, but I also can't stay here." (edited)

Sam's presence is interesting, because he seems to act the same as he does in the real world. That makes sense, as he doesn't have much about him my mind could latch onto and focus on. Ehn/PC 7/22/2022 12:42 PM
There's a new Carlfield.
Hav Kerloe 7/22/2022 12:43 PM
WOOOOOOOO LET'S FUCKING GO I read it.
Ehn/PC 7/22/2022 12:49 PM
Hav Kerloe 7/22/2022 1:05 PM
Hmmm... There's a lot to think about with this one. As expected of Carlfield, it's another intellectually stimulating work. Also as expected, the "joke" itself is not funny at all. Carlfield is lazy, and that's the joke. He's excited about getting food from a dumpster, but since it's across town, he doesn't want to walk there. There's the double meaning of the absurdity of a dumpster "delivering" food, as nobody works at a dumpster. The joke is smarter than a lot of Carlfield's jokes, but it isn't ideal. What really fascinates me about this comic is the obvious social commentary at play here. Carlfield is satisfied, even excited, over the thought of eating food from a dumpster. Compared to his lasagna, this is nothing, but his life is at the point where he is happy with eating garbage. What Carlfield doesn't understand, however, is that all food is garbage. We eat to stay alive, and the construct of "taste" is meaningless towards whether or not the food accomplishes its goal. Thus, is Carlfield's reaction logical? It's hard to say. He certainly is more in tune towards the relative value of food than the average human, being excited for both lasagna and garbage. However, that excitement level is far too high. For Carlfield to truly develop, he must first understand that both of these are equally unimportant. Carlfield should try eating fish. It will help him understand, I know it will. I can only hope Jim David receives my letter soon and puts my ideas into action. It's time to go. I'm hungry, just like Carlfield. However, my advantage over him is that I fully understand what I am eating and why I eat it. I throw the newspaper in a garbage bin and head into the stairwell.
Ehn/PC 7/22/2022 1:07 PM

Ehn/PC 7/22/2022 1:57 PM

Ehn/PC 7/22/2022 3:24 PM
((hi))
Hav Kerloe 7/22/2022 3:36 PM
The first thing I do is take the can of fish food from the cabinet that I opened yesterday and reopen it. I then pour the requisite amount of food into each of the tanks of fish, going a bit faster than usual, as I risk being late to work today. I then preheat the oven at 425 degrees Fahrenheit, the system of measuring temperature used here in Avengard, New York, The United States. I then turn on the sink, use the soap bottle to put soap on my hands, then wash my hands for exactly 40 seconds. I open the refrigerator, and take out a fresh cod. I place the cod on a cutting board, then close the refrigerator. I then take a knife from the knife drawer, and cut it in several pieces. I remove the bones and discard the tail, but I keep the head. Contrary to popular belief, the head is the best part of eating fish. Consuming the eyes and mouth of the animal, its view into the world, cements the idea that this object of consumption was once a living thing. We see out of our eyes, just like this fish did. I pour some olive oil on the pieces, then add salt for flavoring. I then add some cayenne pepper from a container that carries the spiceâ€”a classic accompaniment for this type of fish. Finally, I peel a clove of garlic and mince it, then add the pieces to the dish. After the oven is finished preheating, I place the cod in it and wait for ten minutes. While waiting, I take a lemon from the lemon bowl (a bowl that is used to store lemons, no other fruits), and cut the lemon in half with the same knife and cutting board I used to cut the cod. I then realize that my lemon bowl is empty, this was the last lemon. I make a mental note to buy more lemons at the lemon store (a store that sells many things, but one I only ever make use of to buy lemons from, which is why I call it the lemon store). After the ten minutes are up, I take the cod out of the oven and place it on a plate. I then squeeze the lemon halves onto it, and discard what remains of the lemon halves' corpses. I then eat the cod using a fork and knife. (edited)

While the dishes are washing, an event that typically takes some time, I take the keys to the apartment and exit the fish room, probably better known as the kitchen. I then lock the door behind me.

Hav Kerloe 7/29/2022 5:06 PM
Another successful day. Before leaving, I head to the storage room and get a replacement pane of glass for the fish display. I then clean up the broken glass and carefully remove the bullet from the ground. Sadly, the fish are contaminated, and cannot be served. They will need to be disposed of. This is not a problem, as fish are easily replaceable. Each individual fish, despite containing a distinct mind and sense of self, functionally exists for humans in a single wayâ€”to be eaten. None of these fish are alive, so they have served their purpose. It's up to me to figure out how to handle them. I slide the pane of glass into place, then get a garbage bag. I use my hands to collect the fish and place them inside the garbage bag. I also take the cell phone I was given out of my pocket and place it in the same garbage bag. I then leave the store, carrying the bag of fish with me, heading back to the apartment.
Ehn/PC 7/29/2022 5:09 PM

Advehnt Guard
Avengard / harriet-and-hav
Hav Kerloe 7/29/2022 5:11 PM
Could you please describe Harriet Kadin's current appearance.
Harriet Kadin 7/29/2022 5:14 PM
Harriet Kadin looks the way she does in my server icon. Additionally, she has some bruises on various parts of her body and her wheelchair is pretty dented.
Hav Kerloe 7/29/2022 5:23 PM
I take note of the fact that there is a Harriet Kadin in front of me. [inner monologue, don't read until after the session is over] Is that a person in a wheelchair? Very curious. Being unable to walk must be hard. What if there was a fish that couldn't swim? It's like that, isn't it? Additionally, she has some bruises on various parts of her body, and her wheelchair is pretty dented. Has she been in some sort of accident? Someone who can't walk is, in truth, no different from any other person. Due to human invention, we take someone with a unique attribute such as the inability to walk, and place them in the same position as anyone else. A wheelchair allows you to move just as anyone else would. Your differences are diminished, and we continue to uphold the status quo. I think of the bag in my hands. A cell phone, among the fish. Is it really any different? Yes, the fish were alive, but they aren't anymore. The cell phone is comparable to a person in a wheelchair, being modified to become on the same level as a fish. It makes total sense. A phone is alive in the same way a fish is from the perspective of a human. They both can do things on their own, but ultimately have no effect on our lives. The fact that fish have some sort of "free will" while a phone does not is irrelevant, as they are both so far beneath us that the distinction stops mattering. Now is a good a time as any. Perhaps if this wheelchaired person sees this perfect metaphor, it will show her a path towards understanding. I take the trash bag that is in my hands, open it, and pour the contents of it (many dead fish and a single cell phone) onto the sidewalk without saying a word. I then continue walking with the empty trash bag still in my hands.

4: Almighty Grasp

Advehnt Guard
Avengard / hav-kerloe
Ehn/PC 8/12/2022 11:02 AM
Hav wakes up the next morning.
Hav Kerloe 8/12/2022 11:02 AM
I wake up. Another morning. I look out the window and see Avengard, the city. I have the same thought I have every morning, that thousands of people are also waking up now. It's an interesting thought, which is fitting, as today is an interesting day. Yesterday was also an interesting day, as was every day before that. Nothing was different about yesterday, of course. I can't think of anything that would be. It was as normal a day as any other. On normal days, I work at the fish store, which I own. I look at the fish tank that I keep in the bedroom. Normally, there would be a container of fish food next to it, however I have unfortunately forgotten to place the new cans I bought there. This is a significant oversight, and I curse myself for not being able to complete such a simple task. I will now need to go to the fish room, also known as the kitchen, to get the fish food, and then bring it back to the bedroom. What an inefficient thing to do, however it must be done. I get out of bed and leave the bedroom.
Ehn/PC 8/12/2022 11:03 AM
The doorbell rings.
Hav Kerloe 8/12/2022 11:05 AM
Oh no. What could this be? The doorbell doesn't usually ring here. It shouldn't have a reason to. It's fine, it certainly isn't important. Out of all the possible events that could be transpiring outside of the apartment's door, none of them matter. I ignore the doorbell and continue towards the cabinet with the fish food.
Ehn/PC 8/12/2022 11:07 AM

Hav Kerloe 8/12/2022 11:08 AM

11:09 AM
After this, I leave the bedroom and return to the fish room, feeding the fish in that room as well.
Ehn/PC 8/12/2022 11:09 AM
This happens.
Hav Kerloe 8/12/2022 11:28 AM
I then go to the restroom to brush my teeth. As I am doing this, my mind wanders to the idea of fish brushing their teeth. Why don't fish brush their teeth? Really, why do humans even brush their teeth? Is there some fundamental difference between human teeth and fish teeth that causes this difference in behavior? I understand what I must do. I take the toothbrush, and bring it into the fish room. I then go into one of the fish tanks, take a fish out of it, and pry open its mouth. I attempt to shove the toothbrush into it.

Ehn/PC 8/22/2022 7:55 AM
((Saturday))
Ehn/PC 8/27/2022 2:01 PM
There is also a section in the newspaper where John David responds to fan mail.
Hav Kerloe 8/27/2022 2:32 PM
What a fascinating strip, as expected of Carlfield. First, the joke. We can look at this one on several levels, but the most noteworthy aspect of the joke is in how Carlfield's opinion of himself contrasts with James's analysis of his actions. This type of distinction can create a very comedic scenario, as James represents the average reader's view of society, and Carlfield represents what the average reader truly wantsâ€”a life free from responsibilities. It's "relatable" in that way. Indeed, the underlying message here could not be clearerâ€”John David is telling us that Carlfield believes in this lifestyle, and through that, he's saying that this lifestyle is wrong. Carlfield is demonized for having this belief, and the fact that he isn't a responsible worker like James makes it clear that he lacks a certain quality that drives humans to do workâ€”motivation. Carlfield, however, is not a human, and therein lies another one of the major themes of the Carlfield sagaâ€”the divide between human and animal, and how it's not necessarily as clear-cut as one might imagine. Carlfield is here, struggling against human perceptions of responsibility, and what he should do. But Carlfield's thought process is the same, his sentience is the same, and his way of living is the same. Being an exploration of the human experience through the lens of a nonhuman figure is the core thesis of Carlfield, and this strip exemplifies it greatly.
2:32 PM
I decide to check out the section in the newspaper where John David responds to fan mail.
Ehn/PC 8/27/2022 2:44 PM
"Fan Mail 1:
To John David, creator of Carlfield I think that it would be very interesting if you were to have a Carlfield comic strip in which Carlfield must confront the ways his beloved lasagna is made. He would be disgusted at first, but he would realize that there is no reason to be discomforted by this, and understand that he always knew that his lasagna would be made like this. Seeing it makes no difference. This realization could also potentially spur Carlfield into understanding why his hatred of Mondays is illogicalâ€”he is a cat, not a human. Human logic does not matter to him. I do not require credit for use of my idea. Thank you, Hav Kerloe (owner of Kerloe Fishery)
Thank you very much for your input, Hav! Iâ€™m always glad to hear the requests of devoted fans, and the Carlfield team loved your clear devotion for the work they put in every day. These comic strips are more than just a hobby, or even a job. You could consider them almost like my entire life. Theyâ€™re my legacy. And every day, I wake up happy to know people more creative than me love and appreciate that lovable orange cat. Youâ€™re right, maybe human logic doesnâ€™t matter to Carlfield. But despite this fact, he still chooses to apply it to his life anyway. Maybe life is not as simple as human logic, or cat logic. Perhaps just as Carlfield enjoys lasagna, we may enjoy cat food in the world of comic strips. Thank you so much for your devotion to Carlfield."
Hav Kerloe 8/27/2022 2:52 PM
...Wow. Finally, a response. It's clear he is taking my recommendation into consideration, which is good. His final point fascinates me. May humans enjoy cat food in the world of comic strips? I've tried fish food before, but cat food is a different story. I obviously do not own any cats, so naturally I also do not own any cat food. John David's recommendation is an invaluable one, howeverâ€”I must trust the words of someone who understands so much about the world. Carlfield specifically choosing to apply human logic is also interesting. He's attempting to put himself on the level of humans, that's his desire. And he succeeds. In a perfect world, all animals would understand what Carlfield does. Perhaps what we need is to turn the world into John's "world of comic strips". Before going to sleep, I must do something. I take the newspaper with me and head to Braun Fishery.
Ehn/PC 8/27/2022 2:57 PM

Ehn/PC 9/3/2022 4:56 PM
Hav arrived at his apartment.
Hav Kerloe 9/3/2022 7:38 PM
It's time to test something. I open up the can of cat food. I look inside and attempt to smell it. What does it look like and smell like?
Ehn/PC 9/3/2022 7:38 PM
It looks and smells like a can of fish.
Hav Kerloe 9/3/2022 8:02 PM
WHAT THE FUCK??????????????????????? THIS CHANGES EVERYTHING????????????????????????????? It smells like fish! Fish!!!!! Not only that, but it looks like fish! Do cats eat fish????? I had a plan for what I was going to do, but I'm completely caught off-guard now. This is incredible. You're telling me that Carlfield, the representation of all that is true in the world, decides to eschew his cat food, which is made of fish, for his lasagna? This is... Utterly brilliant! I can't believe I spent any time doubting John David's genius! He knows exactly what he is doing. He knows far more than I do, that's certain. I take a moment to reflect on what I am wearing. White suit, bandages to cover the face. An appearance masked by a distinct yet plain outer layer. Why do people consider this, a covering of all that individualizes you, a unique or strange way to be? Why is the default state one of difference between all people? WHY DOES THE CAN OF CAT FOOD HIDE THE EXTREME IMPORTANCE WITHIN? The fact is that there is fish inside the can. Just as there is a skeleton in every human. These fish are processed, cut up, and packed tightly into cans to be shipped off and enter the inside of a cat. The core of their being, their destiny, is hiddenâ€”never to be truly understood by human observers. Perhaps this is why humanity is so ignorant. If reality was entirely clear, it would cease to be the same reality. If distinctions between individuals cannot be made, recognition of the illogical nature of distinctions would be unnecessary. Is that what Carlfield represents? His world is one where Mondays are dreaded, despite this not making any sense from his perspective. His world is one where he loves lasagna, despite his own designated food being fish of all things. Carlfield is a comprehensive attack on the benefits of uniquenessâ€”his most notable traits are ones that do not function under any scrutiny, he is in complete denial of everything around him, and he is miserable. Over and over, Carlfield is punished for attempting to leave the position he belongs in. The statement John David is making is revolutionary. I can only imagine the calamity that would befall human society if his true intentions were known by the masses. I was going to eat the fish food, but I can't do that now. This is far too important a symbol to be carelessly consumed like that. I decide instead that I should burn it, in hopes that some trace amount of the smoke will reach the inside of John David's nostrils, out of respect for how much he's accomplished. I take a matchbox from my matchbox box (a box full of matchboxes) and attempt to light a match.
Ehn/PC 9/3/2022 8:06 PM
((Roll))
Hav Kerloe 9/3/2022 8:12 PM
((Fourteen))
Ehn/PC 9/3/2022 8:14 PM
The match is lit.
1
Hav Kerloe 9/3/2022 8:14 PM

Ehn/PC 9/3/2022 8:14 PM

Hav Kerloe 9/24/2022 10:02 PM
[inner monologue] Hmm... I feel as if this person is very intelligent. He sees my words as "monotonous", and he's right. Everything I say is as such, to minimize any outliers in occurrences. Not many people are able to see through that. When they do, I have to pretend to act oblivious, so they underestimate me. If someone as smart as this person continues to see my words for what they truly are, the world may never be able to move on. As long as I think through everything I say, I will be able to control this conversation and lead this person in the right direction. I will be disappointed if he doesn't end up buying a meal, but it's fine. He needs to see fish as something desirable, and if I give him two free meals, it will condition him into expecting them for free always. While I don't need to be paid, in this case, it's necessary for a long-term commitment. Now, how about my response? He seems to be disappointed that I didn't ask how he was doing. His injury was irrelevant, but to him it mattered. Therefore I must find an excuse for not noticing it. If I say I didn't recognize him, that should be believable. His face wasn't visible for very long, and it was dark out. There's also the matter of Samâ€”it's true that he is here regularly, but him not showing up doesn't mean I'd assume something's wrong. That seems illogical, even from the perspective of someone ignorant. Therefore, I will mention that I did not know about this. I should also express concern hereâ€”people are often worried when someone else is in danger, even someone they don't know very well. I have no idea why, but it will be a useful inclusion to make myself seem inconspicuous. "I'm sorry, I didn't recognize you from before. It won't happen again. And I wasn't aware Sam was missing. I hope he is found soon."

Hav Kerloe 9/24/2022 10:08 PM
[inner monologue] I've answered this question many times. Coming up with an excuse for why I'm here is easy. He told me his assumption, so I'll give him exactly what he expects to hear. I noticeably slow down the speed that I speak when saying this: "Yes, I've always loved fishing."
Bob Smith 9/24/2022 10:09 PM

10:10 PM

Hav Kerloe 9/24/2022 10:24 PM
[inner monologue] Passion? Is that what he wants? I'll give him passion. I can't believe he'd question this. I do care about fish. They represent the most important thing in existence. They are the thing that awakened me, the reason I am able to live. I can't tell him that, I can't explain the real reason why I care. But I can tell him other things. Do I really seem like I'm not interested? That... That wouldn't be good. I have to be seen as interested. I... Because it's important to show how... No... Never mind. It's... It makes perfect sense. I'm passionate because I understand the truth. I can't control that, because I'm human. I'm excited about something I'm interested in. That's right. People are excited about things they care about. That's why I do this. It's not a logical thing to do, but it's a necessary human action. There's no point in fighting back against that, that would be an attempt at differentiating myself. I'm being passionate because it's natural. I have to continue to be passionate, because everyone is passionate. If I'm not passionate, it wouldn't be normal. That's the reason why. "Cooking is wonderful. I do love fish. And how DARE you suggest otherwise. I don't constantly talk about things I'm passionate about, that would be ridiculous. Why should I need to prove that to someone?" I take a deep breath. "Regardless, I will prove it." I begin to verbalize recipes for seafood dishes (both the ingredients and how to prepare them) from memory.

Hav Kerloe 10/8/2022 2:02 PM

Ehn/PC 10/8/2022 2:10 PM
It would indeed be terrible if Hav Kerloe's hard work in preparing fish received no payment or enjoyment for his customers. Of course, itâ€™s obvious fact that Hav enjoys preparing these fish for his own sake, but most people would not be positively receptive to the notion that work they put in, no matter the motivation, would be so openly swept aside. Of course, this goes beyond just Hav. There are many steps along the way between catching the fish, and itâ€™s end state of becoming eaten. Every step of the way requires devoted workers, people who may even be risking life and limb at sea for these creatures. And each of these workers is moving a gear forward. Alone, they donâ€™t accomplish anything at all. But through careful effort, they manage to turn the whole machine forward and produce fish for consumption. Through his actions, Nathan has disrespected not just Hav but all of these people. Thatâ€™s my opinion on the topic, at least.
Hav Kerloe 10/8/2022 2:12 PM
I don't do anything because nothing has happened.
Ehn/PC 10/8/2022 2:30 PM
And nothing continues to happen. Quite a boring day indeed. Naturally, a boring period of time should usually be skipped over, or interrupted by something interesting. But this is fine. I want to experience this for once.

2:31 PM

Ehn/PC 10/8/2022 2:37 PM
This is a funny description. 'I' is clearly a first person pronoun, indicating that this is from his perspective. Heâ€™s clearly not saying it out loud, so that should indicate this is a thought he is having. A burst of language in an endless void of fish. Yet simultaneously, he claims to have no thoughts at all. Is he speaking to himself, instructing himself of silence? Or does this posit a more metaphorical meaning. Thatâ€™s pretty fucking stupid.
2:38 PM
But also rather dull. Thereâ€™s nothing to dissect here. No grand discourse on the meaning of life through the lens of fish, no such interesting ideology. Itâ€™s just a man standing there, waiting. Silent. Thoughtless. Why? What is he doing? Is be waiting for something? Were I to vanish, refuse him any kind of prompt, how long would it take for individual unprovoked action. Would it ever come?
Hav Kerloe 10/8/2022 2:39 PM
I wonder if there's a new Carlfield today.
Ehn/PC 10/8/2022 2:44 PM
Fascinating. Free will entirely directed towards a cartoon cat. Though, obviously, Carlfield is an exact metaphor for all reality, Hav should have absolutely no idea of this. Is this coincidence? A burst of genius? Collective unconscious? No, this is likely pure narrative contrivance. Thereâ€™s no real miracle at play here. Hm. Well, while weâ€™re here, why not?
2:46 PM
Hav conceives this hypothetical Carlfield in his mind.
Hav Kerloe 10/8/2022 3:10 PM
Ah... Now this a brilliant work. There's so much depth here. If I were to summarize this strip, I would describe it as a symbol of how the unrelenting pressure of individuality conflicts with the world's natural order. Carlfield, as is obvious, represents life as it truly is. He represents a struggle to understand the self, a struggle to accept your place in reality. His owner, James, is, in short, confused. He's an ordinary human in the presence of such an indescribable power, and he subconsciously copes with what this results in. The individual, non-concurrent shenanigans that occur show just how volatile their lives are. With the knowledge of the true contents of cat food, an entirely new dimension of analysis is unlocked. This strip revolves around food. In the first panel, health. Things that James believes will make him stronger. Broccoli, spinach, brussels sprouts, tofu, and raisins. All of these are things that Carlfield cannot bear the existence of. There's no reason to be against "healthy" foods. Taste is irrelevant to a being with as much power as Carlfield. The utter incoherence of his desire to maintain the human norms of "good taste = good food" and "bad taste = bad food" is baffling, and this is clearly a conscious choice on John David's part. The "SMACK" in the second panelâ€”what an unbelievable moment. This is a clear representation of the shift in roles, the way Carlfield's smack acts as a punishment for James, the way James's tongue extends to an over-exaggerated length, just like an animal's would. In this moment, James has become the pet, and Carlfield has become the owner. The fragility of the hierarchy between these two beings is put on full display here. After this shift, despite James taking the same actions he does in the first panel, it becomes clear that there is now an entirely different system governing their world. Three pats, and a thought that James is a "good boy"â€”Carlfield, with a single smack, has taken full control of the situation, being able to destroy what society held up in an instant. The metaphorical can of cat food has been opened, revealing the fish inside. James, now under the control of Carlfield, returns to writing his list, this time writing foods that Carlfield believes he likes. The key word there is "believes"â€”Carlfield is a cat, and thus is entirely unburdened by what human perception deems as good or bad. Yet, he still undergoes the same rituals. He places himself in the role of a human and acts out a facsimile of one. In doing this, John David has illustrated something truly revolutionaryâ€”an expression of the weakness of human roles, and a demonstration of their shallowness. (edited)
Ehn/PC 10/8/2022 3:37 PM
This comic has clearly flown far over Hav's understanding of these comics. Of course, these comics dissect human consciousness and their social structures. Thatâ€™s what they were designed to do. All of them serve as a scathing critique of everything that drives humanity. Pointing this out on its own isnâ€™t complex analysis, itâ€™s the expected bottom line of quality. Should a story be praised for even completing its most basic expected functions? Of course not. There is so much more to it.
Hav Kerloe 10/8/2022 3:38 PM
I have nothing more to say about the comic.
Ehn/PC 10/8/2022 3:41 PM
Perhaps heâ€™ll get it in retrospect. Better to give him time to let it all sink in.
Hav Kerloe 10/8/2022 3:43 PM
I let the comic sink in. I can't seem to think of anything else. I'm sure I've understood everything.
Ehn/PC 10/8/2022 3:45 PM
I suppose I should let time advance meaningfully. This recontextualization will be truly powerful when it comes across naturally. Bob Smith arrived with an unfamiliar girl. ((End session))

Hav Kerloe 10/22/2022 4:18 PM
"No, unfortunately." [inner monologue] Ghost animals? I did see that cat the other day... Or was that a dream? I don't... Wait, no, of course it was a dream. Cats cannot talk. This makes complete sense. It was a dream, and him mentioning something similar is a coincidence. I really wish this man would stop talking. However, his life has value, his perception of me has value, and I cannot do anything to stop him or stop myself from hearing him. As a stepping stone to understanding the reality of existence, any additional contribution to my work here is invaluable. The more he talks, and the more I respond to him, the more he'll get used to me. The more he'll think of our interaction as normal. And when he does that, he'll be perfectly primed to become a functioning cog in the machine that is humanity. He can let go of the idea that he himself matters, and reach a true equilibrium with the world. This interaction, as uncomfortable as it is, will be worthwhile as a step towards that.

Ehn/PC 10/16/2022 12:25 PM
6: Altered Grounds
Advehnt Guard
Avengard / hav-kerloe
Ehn/PC 10/29/2022 2:01 PM
Hav woke up in his bed the next day.
Hav Kerloe 10/29/2022 2:09 PM
I wake up. Yet another normal morning. I get out of bed and look out the window. How interesting that, despite the apartment I live in being ransacked, the city still moves as normal. It's a testament to how uncaring the world is of the concerns of others. This is good. I don't let it bother me, and nobody else should, either. It's Saturday, so I don't have to open the store until an hour later than usual. Thus, I have woken up an hour later than usual. That only makes sense. Only two more days left until the fabled Monday, the most meaningful day of the week. Yet, the only reason it has any meaning is because it's identical to the rest of them. The contradiction between the Carlfield-related obsession with individuality and the truth of social constructions reveals that all that is compelling in reality is a result of society as a whole developing concepts that only act to impede itself. I turn my eyes towards the tank of fish. Is the fish food that I keep on the table next to the tank of fish in the bedroom still on the table?
Ehn/PC 10/29/2022 2:14 PM
The fish food is still there.
Hav Kerloe 10/29/2022 3:20 PM
I LOVE THE FISH FOOD. I take the fish food and use it to feed the fish. Then, I walk out of the room and into the fish room and use the fish food to feed those fish as well. After that, I head to the bathroom to brush my teeth. An interesting activity to ponder; it's something we must do every day, always the same. I should embrace this action, somehow. It feels important, like I'm accomplishing something by partaking in it. Preparing myself to be a person, surviving in the world in the same way as everyone else. Existing in a way that others don't question my presence. I don't really care if my teeth rot and fall out, but maybe brushing them gives an increase to other things that do matter. I head out of the apartment after that and lock the door behind me.
Ehn/PC 10/29/2022 3:22 PM
This happens.
Hav Kerloe 10/29/2022 3:22 PM
I head to the stairwell and walk DOWN the stairs.
Ehn/PC 10/29/2022 3:25 PM
This happens.
Hav Kerloe 10/29/2022 3:28 PM
I take a look around the lobby after exiting the stairwell.
Ehn/PC 10/29/2022 3:28 PM
It's empty.
Hav Kerloe 10/29/2022 3:30 PM
I check the MAIL.
Ehn/PC 10/29/2022 3:31 PM
New Carlfield.
Hav Kerloe 10/29/2022 9:38 PM
Oh my goodness... I don't... This is absolutely mind-boggling. Where to even begin? John has done it again. Ironically, I think to understand this best, we must first look at the ending, separate from the rest of the story. Carlfield is afraid of root canals. That makes sense from a human perspectiveâ€”it's an invasive and uncomfortable dental procedure. However, what about from the perspective of Carlfield, the cat? Do cats brush their teeth? I'm not actually sure. I know fish don't, and I've tried it and it didn't work very well. But cats eat food, so why don't they brush their teeth? Why don't they go to the dentist? That's the question John David is asking here. Again, this strip reflects Carlfield's desire to become one with humanity, to reach the thing he can never reach. However, the first two panels add an entirely new dimension to Carlfield's dynamic with the world around him. Carlfield is watching television, bored. He doesn't care about the vampire. That makes sense, as a vampire isn't real. And what Carlfield desires most of all is something real, something that he can hold onto. However, when confronted with a factâ€”this vampire is experiencing a human experience, and this is real, what Carlfield feels is fear. Despite the fact that he must confront the reality of himself, he has a natural reaction of terror. And this, further, pushes the core message of Carlfieldâ€”the world is being blended together. The vampire is undergoing a normal human procedure, the cat is having normal human reactions. The aspects of themselves that cause them to be seen as different are rendered irrelevant. Through this metaphor, John David's beliefs are illuminated clearly, and in one of the cleverest ways I've seen yet.
9:41 PM
If nothing else happens, I leave the apartment complex. But you're typing so I assume something else happens. (edited)
Ehn/PC 10/29/2022 9:48 PM
The vampire itself additionally adds a very interesting layer to the whole thing. They suck blood. Like leeches. In order to survive, they must constantly live off of humans and suck them dry until nothing is left. This is what Carlfield does as well, he requires his human owner to feed him at every turn. Abusing him in turn, Carlfield takes everything and gives nothing in return. Foolish as he is however, he allows Carlfield to stay. And for what? Company. A mere mindless dog like he also owns would suffice. He has no need for Carlfield, he has no need to tolerate it's existence. And yet he does. Because humanity, and every side of humanity Carlfield represents, fundamentally cannot exist without inflicting harm upon each other. That is the cruelty of humanity. They all suck each other dry, just to live another miserable day on this earth. Carlfield watches a movie about a vampire, and in essence, every other human being in existence, but he is only surprised at the mere thought that someone could exist without this leech-like relationship. Do not be scared. I am not a parasite. Many people say these words, all liars. But this one grants a true and vaiid reason. He truly cannot hurt this person. In a world of absurdist fiction, there is such a thing as a truly happy friendship. Like Harriet Kadin and Sarah Stanley, in a sense. The ideal human relationship. Carlfield stares into the eyes of optimism, and sees it's true evil. Optimism, a promise of a perfect world no one could ever attain. That is the evil that terrifies Carlfield. So far my best work, I believe. John David is truly a genius author. Hav Kerloe leaves the apartment complex.
9:48 PM

Hav Kerloe 12/21/2022 12:54 PM
It makes sense. Our goals are the same. We are in complete equilibrium. Homeostasis. The return to a place where we can perceive our surroundings as they truly are. I know what I must do. So does my brother. We understand each other so well... Together, we are unstoppable. I have to do what I always do. We have to go. But where? What places are there to go? There's this...I suppose one could describe it as "innate"; the desire to escape, to leave, to find something else. For whatever reason, we're built with this desire to experience something new. And yet, the thing that breaks that desire is trust. The knowledge that everyone understands. You don't need to take any risks if you know that we can all see ourselves in the same way. That's what he must be doing. Building a world in which everyone has that amount of trust. We all can control each other. Once we accept that we can control nothing, that isâ€”then we can control everything. We can become a singular whole. And I know that those he interacts with are...well we can't exactly expect them to understand. They are being conditioned. In the pursuit of inner sanctity we all see the solution as something different. Which is not good. Which is why running out of fish is such a serious concern. What will I do if the fish are gone? How will I communicate what my brother wants me to communicate? I cannot. I must leave it to him. As he said...I have to lay low. Do what I always do. It won't be the same, but that's alright. "I can't." (edited)

This concern is too insignificant. As this continues, my annoyance towards myself compounds. I can't let that happen. I don't need to be upset at myself. Hav Kerloe 1/21/2023 4:26 PM
[inner monologue] Hmm... I might need to begin to question my assumptions a bit more. Since Carlfield is so accurate to the fabric of reality, a Carlfield-style cat with human motivations might be expected, in theory. However, Carlfield is merely a depiction, not something that truly exists. He symbolizes the ways John David sees the world, he exists as an amalgamation of features designed to illustrate the hypocrisy of modern society, the ways people unnecessarily allow their own emotions to be controlled. Yet would it really be so strange to have something like that actually exist? People can do incredible thingsâ€”they can make robots, costumes of dinosaurs that speak and convey information. And these existences are here for us to witness and notice how covering up human free will and ability to communicate with something unassociated with those concepts breaks down our preconceived notions. When I see a talking cat, that right there is the problem. Society gives me the pure, unquestionable assumptionâ€”this cannot be real. I am witnessing an impossibility. But when I read Carlfield, perhaps that is yet another message it's trying to conveyâ€”that we can take something unreal and place it in a simulated reality, a comic strip, and we won't question anything. A cat with thoughts, a voice, emotions, and decisions is not out of place in the world. It does not matter how much it speaks. It does not matter how much a fish struggles, as I slice it up and serve it on a plate. It does not matter how much Carlfield continues to hate Mondays. We all let our lives be defined by constructs of societyâ€”that days of the week are real, that people have "more" free will than other organisms, that free will even matters in the first place. Real freedom is letting yourself completely remove your own feelings from the equation when making decisions. Do not choose. You shouldn't be able to say anything. Your happiness will dwindle if you are ever invested in the result. What I must do is break free of those assumptionsâ€”denounce society, and embrace Carlfield. As hard as I try, I still fell victim to the same thing I did previously. Carlfield is right here, right in front of me. That's NOT out of the ordinary. It is normal. My brother wants me to continue as normal? Well, normal is all I can be. I have no desire to ever distinguish myself. I refuse to take any action. That's why I'm here. "...How do you feel about Mondays?"
Marco Gould 1/21/2023 4:27 PM
"What are Mondays?"

Ehn/PC 2/18/2023 2:31 PM

Hav Kerloe 2/18/2023 2:40 PM
As the oven heats up, I take some flour out of the flour cabinet and place it in a bowl. Afterwards, I pour some salt into the flour. Then I take two eggs, crack them into a different bowl, and use a whisk to whisk them until they are sufficiently whisked. Finally, I take a box of bread crumbs and pour them into another bowl. After this, I wash my hands. Then, I take two frozen haddock fillets out of the freezer and coat them in the flour, then the egg, then the bread crumbs. I pour some canola oil into a pan and heat up the stove, placing the fish onto the pan. By now the oven should almost be finished heating up, so I take some potatoes from the potato bowl and cut them into large sticks. I place them on a baking sheet and put it in the oven. After this, I take a spatula and turn over the fish on the pan. Once the fish is complete, I take it and place it on a paper towel over a cutting board to dry, then turn off the oven. I take the potatoes out of the oven and season them with salt and pepper, then take some rosemary from the rosemary container and sprinkle it on top as well. Finally, I take the now dry fish and place it on the plate along with the potatoes. I instinctively go to the lemon bowl (which is a bowl that specifically exists to store lemonsâ€”there are no other fruits that are kept there), but notice thatâ€”oh no, there aren't any lemons left! I must have forgotten to go to the lemon store (the store that I use to buy lemons; although it does sell other things aside from lemons, I have never bought other things besides lemons there). That's alright, however; although my dinner will be lacking some flavor, it will still be sufficient. To make up for the lack of lemons, I take some mayonnaise from the refrigerator and scoop a bit onto the fish. I then eat using a fork and knife. (edited)

Ehn/PC 4/15/2023 8:48 AM
8: Abrupt Gearshift
Advehnt Guard
Avengard / hav-kerloe
Ehn/PC 4/19/2023 2:31 PM
Hav woke up in his bed.
Hav Kerloe 4/19/2023 2:54 PM
Another normal morning. I look out my window at the city of Avengard. It's worth noting that at the present, thousands of other people are also waking up in the same city. That's quite interesting. Today is Monday, the first day of the week. I should be getting ready for work (at Kerloe Fishery, the fish store I work at). I feel fulfilled thinking about how I'm continuing to maintain my presence as a member of society. On Mondays, I have more business than usual, which is a positive development, as more business means more success, and more success is a good thing. It's ironic how the reality of Monday is so distinct from the Monday that Carlfield from the Carlfield comic strip perceives. Indeed, as I've come to realize, this is indicative of John David's satirization of human conceptions, as well as his argument that assumptions of reality are inherently nonsensical. Carlfield is a construct of modern society, and yet his existence is "abnormal" in nearly every sense. Carlfield exists to trick the mindless reader into thinking certain ways about thingsâ€”if you're unable to think critically regarding the truth of your place in the world, then naturally, your reaction will be that an exaggerated form of the truth is amusing. It cannot be accepted, no matter what. Since it's morning, I get up to feed some of the fish. The fish haven't eaten in a while, so it will be good to feed them. Fish need to eat. They can't communicate their hunger, though. All the same, even if they could, surely they would be ignored. When someone sees a homeless person on the street communicating their hunger, it's the same way. It's not their responsibility, because they're different individuals. They can't feel anything for the homeless person. Just as they cannot feel anything for the fish, who are damaged by society's flawed perceptions of individuality in the same way. I step out of my bedroom into the fish room (more commonly referred to as the kitchen), in order to feed the other fish. Next, I head to the restroom to brush my teeth. Brushing one's teeth is important, though it's hard for me to determine exactly why. I think it might be a good idea to stop brushing my teeth. Fish don't have to brush their teeth, so why should I? I search through my memory to see if Carlfield has any commentary on brushing teeth, but I can't think of anything. I take my keys and exit the apartment.
Ehn/PC 4/19/2023 2:55 PM
The hallway is normal.
Hav Kerloe 4/19/2023 2:56 PM
I head down the stairs to the lobby. I always take the stairs. There's no reason to risk running into other people on the elevator. (edited)

I assumed you wouldn't be particularly knowledgable on the subject, so I went for the easier comparison. Generally, 'sashimi' refers to the raw fish eaten on its own without seaweed or rice, and is still quite commonly consumed, despite not being nearly as culturally popular as the more full meal that is sushi rolls. Typically, people consider both sashimi and sushi rolls to be a subset of 'sushi', even if that's not technically correct." (edited)
